LETTER OF TRANSMITTAL John H. Morehead, Governor of Nebraska. Sir: — We herewith transmit to you, as required by law, the biennial report and statement of expenditures made by this Board from December SI, 1914 to December 1, 1916. Original vouchers for all claims are on file with the state auditor of public accounts and duplicates of the same are on file in the office of the Board of Education. Respectfully submitted. A. L. CAVINESS, Secretary.

BIENNIAL REPORT 5 BIENNIAL REPORT To Governor John H. Morehead: The services rendered the people of our state by its Normal Schools Is a most intimate and a most vital one. The teacher* of the boys and girls of today must be well trained for their important work. And the schools that prepare these teachers must be of the highest order of efficiency as educational institutions. That a training school for teachers may be in every sense efficient It must possess a strong faculty, ample and complete equipment, and the full confidence of the people it serves. FACULTY Each of our schools is especially fortunate in having a devoted group of earnest and enthusiastic men and women on Its faculty. During the past two years a few of our strongest educators have been called to other states by the lure of better pay or a wider field of usefulness. But by a process of careful seler-tion and by a conservative and graded salary in - crease the Board of Education has found it possible not only to make good every vacancy but for the most part to retain our most experienced ■workers. MATERIAL EQUIPMENT Enlightened economy at times demands the liberal expenditure of money. A great industrial plant calls for the outlay of millions of dollars before it is expected to yield any returns whatever. The greatest Industry <>t this nation, educating its children, can not produce the highest and best results if its material equipment be inadequate and of an inferior sort. The Board of Education has therefore deemed it wise to use all avail - able funds, after providing for the proper maintenance of each school, in erecting such buildings as will meet the most urgent and immediate de - mands of each institution. The training school at Peru, begun In the last biennium, has been completed, as has also the administration building 1 at ■Wayne. Out of the funds of this biennium there is being built an auditorium and a physical education building at Kearney, a physical and an Industrial building at 'Wayne, and an east wing to the main building at Chadron. When completed these buildings will supply temporarily at least the im - perative needs of the three new and growing schools, leaving the ollsr school at Peru to be cared for as future resources may permit.

6 STATE BOARD OF EDUCATION EXTENSION WORK People have confidence only in the things with which they are familiar. To extend their usefulness and bring more teachers In contact With the schools study center classes have been organized in many places. Faculty members meet these classes on Saturdays and so assist ambitious worker* who are anxious to improve themselves while actively engaged in teaching. Our normal school (acuities visit institutes, attend teachers' meetings. fend seek to render expert assistance wherever needed. They follow up the work of their graduates and help to make it a success. In fact, these insti - tutions are doing- for the school interests of Nebraska a work similar to that done by schools of agriculture for the fanning industry of our country. The act of the legislature requiring the Board of Education to provida special instruction for rural teachers has been complied with in each of the normals. Rural departments, with trained specialists in charge, have been established and every effort is being made to help the teachers of the country schools. Without doubt this is a field that deserves our most care - ful attention. BUILDINGS From the funds of last blennium a west wing to the main building at .Chadron was provided for, an administration building at Wayne, and a training school at Peru. Kearney has received first attention in the build - ing program of this biennium. A contract was let August t, 1915, for an auditorium to cost $ST,867.oo and this building will soon be ready for use. On June 23, 1916, contracts were signed for a physical education build - ing at Kearney to cost $52,195.00, an east wing for Chadron to cost »5] ,548.00, and a physical and Industrial building for Wayne to cost S64.S92.00. These buildings should be completed during the coining sum. tner, and they will serve to relieve the crowded conditions now prevailing at each of these schools. FUNDS The money appropriated by the the normal schools as reported by the foUowing: last legislature for the support of state auditor's office amounts to the liaised from the 1915 tax levy Raised from the 1916 tax levy Raised from the 1913-1914 tax levy. Interest on Endowment Fund to Dec, $367,822.84 . 383,132.86 59,350.19 1, 1916 15,808.24 $826,114.13 Out of the above funds there was set aside as maintenance for each school during the biennium: To Chadron $85,000.00. Kearney $160,000.00, Peru $180,000.00. Wayne $120,000.00 or a total of $545,000.00. This left sm.U4.is for buildings, other expenses and permanent improvements for all the schools.

BIENNIAL REPORT T ESTIMATES It will require a material increase for maintenance during the coming biennium, due to caring for additions to the physical plants, larger number of teaching force to accommodate the increased enrollment at each school, and the increased cost of up-keep and repairs. The present levy of 85-1M of one mill should remain unchanged.

CHADRON STATE NORMAL SCHOOL 15 CHADRON STATE NORMAL SCHOOL CHADRON, NEBRASKA ROBERT I. ELLIOTT. President Chadron, Nebraska, December 1, 1918. To the Honorable Board of Education of the State Normal Schools' Gentlemen: — I hereby submit a report of the condition of the Chadron State Normal School for the past biennium and some suggested improve - ments for the next biennium. AGRICULTURAL EXTENSION A place will be set apart on the campus for agricultural purposes — a bain built, live stock purchased and a man hired to look after gardening, the live stock, the campus and such odd Jobs as may come up from time to time. This agriculture work will be started as soon as possible next spring. In providing our own vegetables, milk, pork, etc., we will, in my opinion, more than pay the expenses of the extra man and the purchase of the live stock. We have a campus of eighty acres and there is ample room for such a demonstration farm. Such a farm has already been authorized by the Board. NEW BUILDINGS We are in need of some new buildings. When the present building; is completed, we must begin to plan for a modern gymnasium and an audi - torium that will be adequate for the needs of the school. With the comple - tion of the present building, we will have plenty of class room, but we have no place at present, except the Railroad T. M. C. A. gymnasium for physi - cal training work. I am very anxious that we have a gymnasium as soon as the funds will permit. The Y. M. C. A. is about a mile from the present Normal site. ATTENDANCE The attendance is gradually increasing and I look for a marked in - crease in the near future. Many of the high school graduates of the west - ern section of Nebraska are looking this way for general training, and the graded as well as the country schools in western Nebraska are looking to this school for teachers. We have had between fifteen and twenty calls for teachers from the best schools in western Nebraska, during the past

16 STATE BOARD OF EDUCATION month. Thi« shows the need for our institution, and as soon as the young people fully realize the advantages of this school, and the opportunities offered to teachers, many more will come here to finish the teachers' courses. STUDY CENTER We are organizing study centers in our territory and the instructors are always ready to spend their Saturdays in carrying on this work where ten or more students get together to pursue one or more lines of study. I believe there is a great field in this extension work, and we are going to give a great deal of attention to this in the near future. FACULTY We have a splendid faculty both in the Normal school proper, and the training school. Most excellent work is being done. In order to carry on the work properly, we must add some courses which other normal schools now have. In order to do this, we will need more instructors for the next biennium. The work in expression and drawing is now conducted by two of the training school teachers, the physical training is under the direction of one of the English teachers. While these teachers are doing excellent work, yet we will need someone who can devote ail her time to these lines in order to get the best results. We have yet no art department in con - nection with the Normal School. This, it seems to me. is one of the neces - sary departments in a state normal school. There is a splendid feeling and excellent spirit among the students of the school as well as the faculty. We have organized an orchestra, which is conducted by one of the members of the faculty. Basket ball and foot bail teams are in training. It is our purpose to get the students of the school to take part in one or more of the various organlations of the Insti - tution. It is our final purpose to dev elope the young people who come here, so that they may be able to go out into the world and do the most for humanity. Respectfully submitted, ROBERT L ELLIOTT, President. CHADRON Financial Report for Biennium, Beginning December 1, 1914, and Ending December 1, 1916. 30 STATE BOARD OF EDUCATION KEARNEY STATE NORMAL SCHOOL KEARNEY, NEBRASKA GEORGE S. DICK, President Kearney, Nebraska, December 1, 1916. To the State Board of Education: My dear Sirs: — I beg to submit herewith a report of the condition of hte finances, the progress, and the needs of the State Normal School at Kearney, for the biennium beginning December 1, 1914, and ending De - cember 1. 1916. Very respectfully. GEORGE S. DICK. President. Kearney. Nebraska, December 1. 19L6. I hereby certify that the attached report, covering the finances of the State Normal School at Kearney from December 1, 1914, to December 1, 1S16. is true and correct to the best of my knowledge and belief. GEORGE S. DICK, President. Subscribed in my presence and sworn to before me this 23rd day of December, 1916. J. S. ELLIOTT, (SEAL) Notary Public. DEVELOPMENT OF THE SCHOOL In planning for the growth and development of this institution, our report will take into consideration the following: I. The needs of a fully equipped State Normal School at Kearney, II. Kearney's present condition — the part of this equipment already here. III. Material equipment necessary to complete the plant. THE NEEDS OF A FULLY EQUIPPED TEACHERS' SCHOOL If a teachers' school is to successfully serve the people, its equipment must be good in these five lines: (1) Faculty. (2) Libraries and Labora - tories. (S) Buildings and Furniture. (4) Campus, Playgrounds, Garden and Farm. (5) Ways and Means of carrying the service to the people — to teachers not enrolled in the institution. FACULTY. Men and women, to carry on this important work and to be responsible for the success of the institution and its service, must be carefully selected for their education, training, and success. They must bo

KEARNEY STATE NORMAL SCHOOL 31 inspiring, sympathetic, and of the highest type of alround Christian char - acter: they must be persons of exemplary habits whose real devotion to service causes them to live effective lives in their spirit of successful co - operation with the other factors that go to make a real teachers' school; they must have in every sense the qualifications and the true spirit of real teachers. LIBRARIES AND LABORATORIES. This faculty muit have the necessary tools that will enable them to do the very best teaching accord - ing to the latest approved educational theory and practice. These tools may be known as Libraries, Laboratories, Equipment and Supplies for both indoor and outdoor work. BUILDINGS AND Fl'RNITURE. These teachers, with their libraries and laboratories, must be housed in substantial, spacious, attractive, suit - ably furnished buildings, with abundance of the right kind of light, heat, and ventilation. LOCATION AND ARRANGEMENT. These buildings should be care - fully located on wisely chosen, artistically arranged, and well kept campus, playgrounds, gardens and fields. The supply of teachers, library, labor - atory, buildings and grounds must be such by selection, classification, ar - rangement, as to meet every need of a student in his education and train - ing. It must be remembered that he is going out to undertake the physical, mental, moral, and spiritual education and training of tomorrow's citizen - s-hip, as he takes charge of the boys and girls of today. EXTENSION WORK AND FOLLOW-UP SERVICE. There must be ways and means of connecting up with people in charge and with others interested in the public schools of the state. With the teachers at work, school officers, patrons and their children, there must be constant and live contact, not only that these may be helped, but also that the teachers' school may be ever alive to real conditions and always alert for improve - ments in matters of teacher training. This phase of service is generally known as "extension work," as It is the way in which the institution and its equipment ii effectively carried out to the people. Among the various ways in which this Rervice is rendered, the following are the most common: (a) Real academic work and entertainment for those unable to enroll in the school. <t>) A study of the organization, management and teaching of the public school for teachers and school officers, (c) Inspirational work — that which follows up all these good things with constant care and helpfulness for those who have graduated from the school as well as for the assistance of the large )>er cent who have not had this valuable train - ing. This «ervice is Justly due every graduate or student who goes out from a Normal School to teach. KEARNEY'S PRESENT CONDITION 1. Three central buildings. There are three central buildings well planned, all under one roof, which is esi>ecially good for the protection.

32 STATE BOARD OF EDUCATION convenience and economy of time to students and helpful in the general management of the school. In these buildings there are offices, halls, reci - tation rooms, laboratories, and an excellent library well planned, finely lighted, and containing nearly 14,000 up to date, carefully selected books well adapted to a teachers' school. The library is in charge of specially trained, very capable and highly appreciated librarians. There is also a well organized training school consisting of kindergarten, primary, grades, and junior high school, furnishing a general laboratory for the application of principles underlying the most modern ideas of school organization, management, teaching and training. In this training school the seniors get their valuable practice. It is now located in crowded quarters and needs better accommodations. 2. Rural demonstration schools. To meet the demand for the training of rural teachers, there are associated with this institution, three demon - stration schools. One, a ten -grade, one-room, two-teacher school six miles east of Kearney. Another an eight-grade, one-room, one-teacher school four miles north. A third now in process of erection, an eight-grade, two - room, one-teacher school three miles west of Kearney. S. Direct work of the Faculty. The various departments are man - aged and taught by well prepared highly successful teachers presenting the most modern courses of study in each particular line according to the latest and best principles of education. 4. The Dormitory. There is one dormitory accommodating about eighty young women. This is presided over by a very capable woman well suited to have charge of a good home for young women. 5. Boarding department. The boarding department accommodates about 260 students in the regular year, and last summer term furnished from 1000 to 1200 meals daily. Excellent board is being served here at $2.75 a week, or 20 cents a meal. The dining room is crowded and boarding facilities should be increased. C. Central heating plant. There is one central heating plant doing good work keeping all rooms, with very little exception, in good condition, even in the coldest weather. Without additional boiler supply it will take care of the auditorium when attached, but this is thought to be the limit of the present capacity . 7. The Auditorium in process of erection. The new auditorium now nearing completion will furnish the school a much needed convenience for general assembly in the various activities of the school — chapel purposes, lectures and entertainments. The third floor of this building, will furnish a home for the Music department (public school, piano, voice, violin) there - by releasing a large room to be used by the English department. The old chapel room will be remodeled and equipped as a home for the Commer - cial department.

KKAHNEY STATE NORMAL SCHOOL 33 v New Cvmnaaium in process of erection. The completion and equip - ment of the gymnasium now in process of erection will (111 a long tilt want. An effective physical education department will be organized, in charge of specialists in this line. This will furnish also a center for the social life of the school— a place very much needed at the present time. There is some playground equipment on the campus, an enclosed athletic park just west of the main building, and west of that a few acres used by classes in agriculture. MATERIAL EQUIPMENT NECESSARY TO COMPLETE THE PLANT The following material equipment Is necessary to complete the plant if it renders to the people the service for which it was foundd: 1. A Training School Building. The characteristic feature of any teachers' school is a well planned, thoroughly equipped, spaciously housed training school. In this we are sadly lacking; hence, one of the first and must imperative needs is — (a) a suitable building to house this depart - ment in keeping with the needs of the school; (b) a well planned and com - plete model rural school building on the campus, that it may be of conven - ient ; ccess fur demonstration and observation in rural teacher-training work. 2. A Farm. A Nebraska law requires that the Normal Schools train rural teachers. In order to do this according to the most approved theory and practice, a suitable tract of land, properly equipped as a small farm, is necessary. S. Greenhouse. The greenhouse allowed last year was not built, aa it was thought best that buildings now in process of erection should be pushed to completion before others were started. It is needed. 4. Industrial Arts Building. The departments of industrial arts are crowing, but are handicapped by the small housing and meager equipment. The trend of the times is indicative of the need of a special building to ac - commodate these departments and the growth that such improved housing and equipment would immediately encourage. 5. Library Building. Today in nearly every line of school work much attention is given to the cultivation of the habit of good reading. Of the nearly 14,000 volumes of books and the fine collection of pictures, faculty and students make excellent use. The present llbiary room is crowded, both as to place for books and for the accommodation of students. A library building will soon be a necessity. 6. More Dormitories. The desirability of dormitory life for young students and the growing demand from our patrons leads us to commend the erection of two more dormitories, one for the use of young women and one for the use of young men. 7. Central Heating Plant. This plant must be enlarged next yew by the addition of one more boiler and the change of coal bins, in order to meet the increased demand for heating of the new gymnasium.

82 STATE BOARD OF EDUCATION PERU STATE NORMAL SCHOOL PERU, NEBRASKA D. W. HAYES. President Peru, Nebraska, December 1, 1916. To the Nebraska State Board of Education: Gentlemen: — I am pleased to submit herewith the biennial report of the Peru State Normal School. This includes a detailed statement of the receipts and expenditures for the biennium up to December 1, 1916, to - gether with an estimate of the funds needed for the next biennium. There is also included a brief outline of the needs of the Peru looking towards it expansion in the sphere of its influence, together with its needs in ma - terial equipment. The year 1916 marks the closing of the first fifty years of Peru's his - tory as a State Institution. Starting as a Methodist Seminary in 18C5, it was turned over to the State of Nebraska and made a State Normal School by the act of the first State Legislature in 1867. Its growth and in - fluence may be measured in a small degree when it is remembered that in that time Peru has grown from a school employing two faculty mem - bers and enrolling but little more than half a hundred students to an insti - tution with a faculty of approximately 40 members and a net enrollment of nearly 1400 students. During this time approximately 30,000 different students have been enrolled in Peru. 2,684 graduates from the advanced courses have gone forth, nearly all of them into the public schools of Nebraska. Some idea of the rapid development of Peru in recent years may be gained by considering the fact that one-half of these graduates have completed their work within the past seven years; and this during a time when the standards of scholarship are at the highest point in the his - tory of the school. The Peru faculty was never better prepared for its particular work than at the present time. Practically all heads of depart - ments have at least the degree of Master of Arts, and all have had a broad, rich experience as school teachers. The President of the school is desirous of expressing to the State Board of Education his appreciation and hearty approval of the methods now employed in financing the State Normal Schools. No one factor has proved of greater importance in broadening the scope of the State Normal Schools' usefulness than the present method of financial support. While the 85-100 of a mill levy may not provide for all the buildings that may be

PERU STATE NORMAL 83 desired, we believe that by rigid economy and a careful method of con- serving the funds that the present 85-100 of a mill will prove adequate for maintaining the State Normal Schools In such manner aa to bring them to a high plane of efficiency. The following is a detailed statement of the enrollment during the biennium beginning with the regular school year, September, 1*14. and ending with the summer school in 1916: Reg. Year S. School Reg. Tear 8. 84 STATE BOARD OF EDUCATION THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE SCHOOL The following brief statement will indicate something of the ideals which should reasonably be expected to be attained within the next few years. In many of these points Peru has already reached these ideals. The Peru State Normal School has never lost sight of the purpose for which it was established; namely, the training of teachers for the public schools of Nebraska. It has ever strived to meet the growing needs of Nebraska's schools by furnishhing, so far as its faculty and equipment would permit, teachers for the different departments of the public schools of the State. Until a dozen years ago there was no other State institution which made any pretense of training teachers for the public schools. Hence, Peru was called upon to furnish many of the city superintendents, high school principals and high school teachers, teachers for the grades, and rural teachers. Peru is still called upon to meet these various requirements of the public schools. It was her mission to set the pace for professional training of teachers, and it is within the scope of her ideals to continue one of the leaders in this grand and noble work. There are needed an - nually at least 600 new teachers in the high schools of the State. It is entirely beyond the power of the University to furnish tenchers to meet this annual requirement. To do so would mean an annual enrollment of at least 3,000 teachers. In fact, at least one or two State Normal Schools will need to bend every effort to assist in the preparation of these teachers if Nebraska is to maintain her place in the field of education. In addition to this, at least 1,300 new grade teachers must be graduated every year in Nebraska in order to fill the ranks of those who drop out of the profession. In addition to this, approximately 2,500 new rural teachers are needed each year. It is needless to say that since at least three-fourths of the money for the support of the State Normal Schools is derived from the country districts the Normal Schools should share in the responsibility for training rural teachers. It is in this direction that the greatest expan - sion of the Normal School should come in future years. Training For Service Believing that a vital part of the training of a teacher is the training which she receives in service, it will be Peru's purpose to increase its use - fulness through its extension department. This will necessitate more liberal expenditures in the development of study centers and correspon - dence work ar begun by the school within the past three years. Rural Department To properly develop our rural education will necessitate a Model Rural School Building that shall be an example of what is expected in ma - terial equipment. To meet the twentieth century ideals in rural school

I'KKl' STATE NORMAL 85 development, there will ne»d to be ample grounds for agricultural demon - stration punxmes. as well as room for the teaching of the industrial arts to the boys and girls on the farm. Buildings and Material Equipment Peru was started when the State was poor. As a result, the older buildings on the campus are of the make-shift type, and are lacking in the permanency that characterizes the buildings of more recent years. To make Peru a complete plant it will be necessary to include in her building schedule a Science Hall to take the place of the old warped frame structure which has been used for that purpose for the past quarter of a century; the building; contemplated should be of modern fire-proof construction to cost approximately $65,000.00. The old main building constructed over forty years ago should be completely overhauled and made into a modern fire-proof structure. When so remodeled it will accommodate the indus - trial and fine arts of the school, such as manual training, domestic science. agriculture, public school art and public school music, clay modeling, and the music departments. It will also furnish rooms for the literary organ - izations. The cost will be approximately 125,000. 00. Peru's building cam - paign would also include an addition to the dormitory. At the present time only about one- fifth of the girls attending the Normal School are able to secure accommodations at the dormitory. Approximately $40,000.00 will be needed for this purpose. The beautiful chapel which was constructed ten years ago contains a fine auditorium but its usefulness is greatly im - paired because of its poor acoustic*. The proper remedy would be either to construct a second ceiling, or to line the room with some sound-absorb - ing material. The cost would be from $3,000.00 to $4,000.00. Campus Improvement and Addition* There must be added to the present campus at least ten acres of ground for demonstration purposes in connection with the Agricultural and Rural departments. This could well be in connection with the rural dem - onstration school building and would serve not only the agriculture stu - dents of the Normal School in all departments, but would be especially advantageous in the training of the teachers who will go into the rural schools. The roadways belonging to the campus should be paved, thus ending a constant source of annoyance from dust and ever recurring repairs. Peru has a beautiful campus of sixty acres — perhaps the finest natural campus in the I'nited States — but much of it is in such a wild state that it cannot be used. A few thousand dollars expended in clearing out the debris, seeding it to suitable grasses, fencing, and further care would make it one of the beauty spots of America. This should, without question, be

86 STATE BOARD OF EDUCATION a part of the plans for the future development of Peru. Also the time will come when It will be necessary to construct a sewer extending through the town of Peru to take care of the sewage from the Normal School grounds. Approximately $160,000.00 to $180,000.00 will provide for the buildings and other material equipment contemplated in the plans outlined, and will render Peru fit for greater efficiency in the service of the State of Ne- braska. 114 STATE BOARD OK El>i;CATH>N WAYNE STATE NORMAL SCHOOL WAYNE, NEBRASKA U. S. CONN, President Wayne, Nebraska, December 1, 1916. To the State Board of Education of Normal Schools. Gentlemen: I am pleased to submit you herewith the biennial report of the Wayne State Normal School. This includes a detailed report of the expenditures during the past two years and an estimate of the needs for the ensuing biennium. The growth of the school has been very gratifying. The most satisfac - tory part of this growth is to be found in the better preparation of those who apply for admission. When the state purchased the Nebraska Normal College the equipment was so poor that very few high school graduates were attracted. The reputation of the place as a school where a short* cheap review course could be had was a positive detriment to the building up of a state normal school. The completion of the Library and Science Hall followed by the completion of the Administration building placed the Wayne State Normal upon an entirely new footing. Since the completion of the Administration building the percentage of the students of college rank has more than doubled This experience has led me to believe that the equipment of an institution must be kept somewhat in advance of the actual needs in order to best serve the interests of the State. Faculty. Practically no change has taken place in the personnel of our faculty since the organization of the school. Each year one or more members of the faculty have asked for a leave of absence in order to prepare them - selves further for their line of work. This policy is encouraged for the reason that it brings new ideas to the institution and keeps the faculty in touch with the* latest advancement in the training of teachers. Within the last four years every member of the training school faculty, including the Dean, has S|>ent from a semester to two years in some eastern professional school. A number of other members of our faculty have also secured leave of absence for study. Without a single exception those who have asked for leave of absence have returned to the institution and have in this man - ner added strength to our already excellent corps of teachers.

WAYNE STATE NORMAL, SCHOOL 115 Extension of Campus. The grounds contain but ten acres. These should be extended on* block to the west, one to the south and half a block to the east, making an addition of seven and a half blocks. Real estate men who are In a position to know the values of adjacent property, estimate that this extension Would be worth about $30,000. These extensions, together with the croaa streets which the city of Wayne will readily abandon, would give a plat of ground containing about twenty-five acres in all for the Normal School. Inasmuch as all of this property is platted and now contains nine small residences and a number of others will doubtless soon be erected, it is a matter of economy to make this investment now and not wait until the price becomes prohibitive. Part of this added ground should be utilized for a proper athletic field, part of It for demonstration in agriculture and another part should be used as a model rural school ground. Training School The old auditorium building has been fitted up and is being used at the present time for a training school. Inasmuch as the training school is the very thing for which the Normal School stands, a better building should be provided than it is possible to make out of the old building. A modern training school should have large, well-lighted school rooms. In this building there should be provision for Domestic Science and Manual Training for the grades. There should also be a consultation room and a number of class rooms, an assembly room for the junior high school and a recreation room to be used by the children on stormy days. It is impos - sible to make such a building of the present one and for this reason an appropriation should be made of not less than $75,000 with which to con - struct a modern, up to-date training school. Modal Rural School On the grounds, but apart from the main buildings, there should be a school equipped as model for rural schools. In this building there Should be conducted an ungraded school made up of the children from near-by districts. The rural people are ready and anxious to transport their chil - dren to such a school. This would be a sane method for the training of rural teachers, as we would have rural children In a rural school being trained under rural conditions. It would take but a minute's time for the student to go from his regular normal school work to the rural school near at hand. To attempt to have a rural school as a demonstration school In the country makes it so inconvenient that it is practically worthless as a training school for rural teacheds.

116 8TATE BOARD OF EDUCATION Each year there has been a gradual Increase In the number of special students until at the present time there are nearly fifty special music stu - dents besides about one hundred fifty enrolled in absentia and study center classes. None of these are Included In our regular enrollment. The total cost of the Normal School to the state for everything except permanent improvements during the years 1914-15 and 1915-16 was approximately $120,000. The combined enrollment for these years, not including the train - ing school, special students and study center students, was 1740. This makes a per capita expense of approximately $69.00. The number of graduates for the six years since the state took over the school is in the advanced courses, 3, 23, 33, 42, 50, 61, for the respective years. The number of those receiving the elementary state certificate during the six years is 86. During the entire time we have had a more or less definite organization in the preparatory department which has sought to give elementary preparation for rural teaching. Classes have been organ - ized for these students in Methods and Management for rural schools. They have been permitted to do observation work. Since no certificate can be granted by the school to these students, all who wish to teach secure county certificates on examination. Several hundred have received train - ing in this way since the organization of the school and have gone into the rural schools where they have rendered creditable service. Their suc - cess and our experience with them convinces me that a well organised rural department in the Normal School would render valuable service to the educational interests of the state.
